\( \def\curl#1{\text{curl }#1} \def\bracket#1{\left({#1}\right)} \def\sbracket#1{\left[{#1}\right]} %square bracket \def\cbracket#1{\left\{{#1}\right\}} %curly bracket \def\Lim_#1{{\lim\limits_{#1}}} \def\limit{{\lim\limits_{n \to \infty}}} \def\dsum{{\displaystyle \sum}} \def\Sum_#1^#2{{\sum\limits_{#1}^#2}} \def\summ{\sum\limits_{n=0}^{\infty}} \def\R{{\mathbb R}} \def\N{{\mathbb N}} \def\fQ{{\mathcal{Q}}} \def\riemannR{{\mathscr{R}}} \def\ep{\varepsilon} \def\d{\displaystyle} \def\grad{\nabla} \def\q{q} \def\mod#1{\left | {#1} \right |} \def\abs#1{\left | {#1} \right |} \def\crossProduct#1{\left\|\begin{array}{ccc} #1 \end{array}\right\|} \newcommand{\partialwrt}[2][]{\frac{\partial {#1}}{\partial {#2}}} \newcommand{\dpartialwrt}[2][]{\dfrac{\partial {#1}}{\partial {#2}}} \def\upint{\mkern3mu\overline{\vphantom{\intop}\mkern7mu}\mkern-20mu\int} \def\lowint{\mkern3mu\underline{\vphantom{\intop}\mkern7mu}\mkern-10mu\int} \def\lowsup_#1{_{{\lower{0.3em}{#1}}}} \)

Let $f_n: \R \to \R$ be defined by $f_n(x) =\dfrac{x^2}{(1+x^2)^n}, (n=1,2,3,...)$
  1. Does $\{f_n\}$ converge pointwise?
  2. Are the functions $f_n$ and the limit function $f$ continuous?
  3. Is the sum of the series $\Sum_{n=0}^{\infty}f_n$ continouos?
  1. \text{For } x \neq 0, & \Lim_{n \to \infty} f_n(x) &= \limit \dfrac{x^2}{(1+x^2)^n} = 0 \\ \text{For } x = 0, & f_n(0) &= 0 \mbox{ for all }n\\ & \Lim_{n \to \infty} f_n(0) &= \limit 0 = 0\\ \mbox{Hence for all } x \in \R, & \Lim_{n \to \infty} f_n(x) &= 0

    Since $\{f_n(x)\}$ converges every $x\in \R$, $\{f_n\}$ converges pointwise.

  2. Each $f_n$ is continuous since it is rational function.

    Since the limit function $f(x)=\limit f_n(x)=0$ for all $x \in \R$, it is a constant function. Hence it is continuous.

  3. \text{For } x \neq 0,& \summ f_n(x) &=\summ \dfrac{x^2}{(1+x^2)^n} \\ &&=x^2 \summ \dfrac{1}{(1+x^2)^n}\\ &&=x^2 (1+\dfrac{1}{1+x^2} + \dfrac{1}{(1+x^2)^2} + \dfrac{1}{(1+x^2)^3}+...)\\ &&=x^2 \dfrac{1}{1-\dfrac{1}{1+x^2}}\\ &&=x^2 \dfrac{1+x^2}{1+x^2-1}\\ &&=1+x^2 \\ \text{For } x = 0,& f_n(0) &= 0 \\ & \summ f_n(0) &= 0

    Define $f(x)=\Sum_{n=0}^{\infty} f_n(x)$ by $f(x)= \begin{cases} 0 & \mbox{ if $x=0$}\\ 1+x^2 & \mbox{ if $x\neq 0$} \end{cases}$

    Draw figure

    The sum of the series is not continuous at $x=0$.
